ground_truth: Pappy is considering the crowd, and he drops one arm around Everett and the other around Delmar. Everett hesitates, uncertain of what is happening, while the band beams and Delmar leans into Everett with worry. Delmar gives Everett a meaningful look, which Everett considers for a moment. Pappy returns a considered appraisal. On the steps of the meeting hall, people stream out of the concert into the warm summer night. Everett, now relieved of his beard, is walking down the steps with Penny and raises her left hand with his own to display their wedding bands, but her finger is bare, and she walks off. His attention, along with everyone else's, is drawn to a street procession where a crowd carrying torches jogs behind a man in clanking leg irons and wrist manacles escorted by four policemen with nightsticks in riot-ready formation. Everett and the Soggy Bottom Boys descend the steps to meet the oncoming criminal, and Delmar cries out. It is George Nelson, grinning despite his heavy restraints, and as he passes, he turns to call back over his shoulder. Delmar, smiling, shakes his head as he watches him go. In the blackness, we hear snuffling getting louder and closer. Inside a cupboard, a snout noses the door open. As the door swings wide, light reveals several neatly stacked tins of Dapper Dan pomade next to a bunch of tangled hairnets. Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy walk through the woods and emerge into a clearing where a cabin stands before them. Two shotgun-wielding goons fall in behind them and push them forward, revealing next to an oak tree three freshly dug graves with rough pine coffins at the far lip of each grave. The sheriff with mirrored sunglasses, Cooley, steps off the porch with a drooling hound at his heels. The goons shove them toward the tree, and three shirtless black gravediggers with bandannas round their necks emerge from the graves and look to Cooley for guidance, as does the drooling hound. The goons recover their leering grins and resume their task while the gravediggers stand next to the graves, leaning on their shovels, with sweat glistening on their faces like tears. Cooley gives a faint smile, and Delmar bows his head to silently pray, followed by Everett. The singing of the gravediggers begins a mournful swell, and the song, seemingly rising from the earth itself, is supported by a palpable bass.

In the darkness, we hear snuffling increasing louder and nearer. Inside a cupboard, a snout pushes the door open. As the door swings wide, light shows several neatly piled tins of Dapper Dan pomade next to a cluster of tangled hairnets. Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy move through the forest and emerge into a clearing where a cabin stands before them. The sheriff with mirrored sunglasses, Cooley, steps off the porch with a drooling hound at his heels. The thugs shove them toward the tree, and three shirtless black gravediggers with bandannas around their necks emerge from the graves and look to Cooley for direction, as does the drooling hound. The thugs recover their leering grins and resume their duty while the gravediggers stand next to the graves, leaning on their spades, with perspiration glistening on their faces like tears. The singing of the gravediggers begins a mournful swell, and the tune, seemingly rising from the earth itself, is supported by a palpable bass.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The crowd is being considered by Pappy, and one arm is dropped by him around Everett and the other around Delmar. Uncertainty about what is happening makes Everett hesitate, while the band beams and Delmar leans into Everett with worry. A meaningful look is given by Delmar to Everett, which is considered by Everett for a moment. A considered appraisal is returned by Pappy. People stream out of the concert into the warm summer night on the steps of the meeting hall. Everett, now relieved of his beard, walks down the steps with Penny and raises her left hand with his own to display their wedding bands, but her finger is bare, and she walks off. A street procession draws his attention, along with everyone else's, where a crowd carrying torches jogs behind a man in clanking leg irons and wrist manacles escorted by four policemen with nightsticks in riot-ready formation. The oncoming criminal is met by Everett and the Soggy Bottom Boys as they descend the steps, and Delmar cries out. It is George Nelson, grinning despite his heavy restraints, and he turns to call back over his shoulder as he passes. As Delmar watches him go, he smiles and shakes his head. Snuffling, getting louder and closer, is heard in the blackness. A cupboard is opened by a snout nosing the door. Several neatly stacked tins of Dapper Dan pomade next to a bunch of tangled hairnets are revealed by the light as the door swings wide. Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy walk through the woods and emerge into a clearing where a cabin is standing before them. They are pushed forward by two shotgun-wielding goons who fall in behind them, revealing next to an oak tree three freshly dug graves with rough pine coffins at the far lip of each grave. Cooley, the sheriff with mirrored sunglasses, steps off the porch with a drooling hound at his heels. The tree is approached by them as the goons shove them toward it, and three shirtless black gravediggers with bandannas round their necks emerge from the graves and look to Cooley for guidance, as does the drooling hound. Their leering grins are recovered by the goons, and their task is resumed while the gravediggers stand next to the graves, leaning on their shovels, with sweat glistening on their faces like tears. A faint smile is given by Cooley, and Delmar bows his head to silently pray, followed by Everett. A mournful swell begins with the singing of the gravediggers, and the song is supported by a palpable bass, seemingly rising from the earth itself.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Pappy considers the crowd, draping one arm around Everett and the other around Delmar. Everett hesitates, unsure of events as the band beams and Delmar leans into him worriedly. Delmar gives Everett a meaningful look, which Everett ponders. Pappy returns a thoughtful appraisal. People stream from the concert into the warm summer night. Clean-shaven, Everett walks with Penny, raising her left hand to display their wedding bands, but her finger is bare, and she walks off. Attention shifts to a procession where a torch-bearing crowd jogs behind a man in clanking irons, escorted by four policemen. Everett and the Soggy Bottom Boys descend the steps. Delmar cries out—it is George Nelson, grinning despite heavy restraints. As he passes, George calls back. Delmar, smiling, shakes his head. In darkness, snuffling grows louder. A snout nudges a cupboard door open, revealing several tins of Dapper Dan pomade and tangled hairnets. Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy emerge from woods into a clearing with a cabin. Two armed goons push them toward three freshly dug graves with pine coffins. Sheriff Cooley, with mirrored sunglasses, steps off the porch with a drooling hound. Goon shove them toward the tree. Three shirtless black gravediggers with bandannas look to Cooley for guidance, as does the hound. The leering goons resume their task, while gravediggers lean on shovels, sweat glistening like tears. Cooley gives a faint smile. Delmar bows to pray, followed by Everett. The gravediggers’ mournful song swells, deeply resonant as if rising from the earth.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Pappy puts an arm around Everett and Delmar. Everett hesitates, while Delmar, worried, leans into him. Delmar gives Everett a meaningful look, and Pappy appraises the scene. People stream from the concert into the warm summer night. Everett, now without his beard, walks with Penny, raising her left hand, but her finger is bare, and she walks off. Attention shifts to a torch-lit procession of a man in leg irons, escorted by policemen. Everett and the Soggy Bottom Boys meet the criminal, George Nelson, who grins despite his restraints. Delmar smiles as Nelson calls back over his shoulder. In the dark, snuffling grows louder. A snout opens a cupboard door, revealing Dapper Dan pomade and hairnets. Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy walk into a clearing with a cabin. Two armed goons push them forward, revealing three fresh graves. Sheriff Cooley steps off the porch with a drooling hound. The goons shove them to the graves, as three shirtless black gravediggers emerge, seeking Cooley's guidance. The gravediggers lean on their shovels, sweating. Cooley faintly smiles, and Delmar and Everett pray. The gravediggers' mournful song swells with a palpable bass.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
Pappy stands thoughtfully, taking in the crowd gathered around, and confidently drapes one protective arm around Everett, while his other arm settles securely around Delmar. Everett finds himself hesitating, unsure and a bit confused about what is unfolding around him. Meanwhile, the band radiates joy, their faces lighting up with smiles, and Delmar leans in close to Everett, visibly filled with worry and concern. Delmar then shoots Everett a meaningful look filled with unspoken communication, which Everett takes a moment to ponder. Pappy returns a thoughtful gaze, considering the scenario before him. On the steps of the meeting hall, people begin streaming out, making their way from the concert into the embrace of the warm, inviting summer night. 

Everett, who is now clean-shaven and without the burden of his beard, walks down the steps beside Penny. He raises her left hand along with his own in a gesture meant to display their wedding bands to the world, but much to his displeasure, her finger remains bare, devoid of any ring, and she quietly walks away. His attention, along with that of everyone else around, is quickly diverted to a street procession. A crowd, fervently holding torches aloft, jogs behind a man encumbered by clanking leg irons and wrist manacles, escorted authoritatively by four policemen in formation, armed with nightsticks and ready for any disturbance. 

Everett, along with the rest of the Soggy Bottom Boys, makes his way down the steps to meet the approaching criminal, and Delmar cries out in recognition. It is none other than George Nelson, grinning broadly despite the heavy restraints that bind him, and as he passes by, he turns his head to call back over his shoulder, his spirit undampened. Delmar, now smiling softly, shakes his head as he watches George disappear into the distance. In the surrounding darkness, a sound of snuffling grows increasingly louder and nearer. Hidden inside a cupboard, a snout slowly pushes the door open. As the door swings fully wide, light falls upon and reveals several neatly stacked tins of Dapper Dan pomade sitting beside a messy heap of tangled hairnets.

Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy make their way through the dense woods and emerge into an open clearing where a cabin stands prominently before them. Two menacing goons, armed with shotguns, fall in line behind them, pushing them ahead. They reveal, next to a sturdy oak tree, three freshly dug graves, each accompanied by a rough pine coffin positioned at the far edge. The sheriff, Cooley, wearing mirrored sunglasses, steps confidently off the porch with a drooling hound faithfully at his heels. The goons continue to shove them forcibly toward the tree. Three shirtless black gravediggers, with bandannas tied around their necks, emerge from the depths of the graves, looking to Cooley for direction, just as the drooling hound does. The goons recover their sinister grins and resume their task, while the gravediggers stand beside the graves, leaning wearily on their shovels, with sweat trickling down their faces like glistening tears. Cooley offers a faint smile, and Delmar bows his head solemnly to pray silently, a gesture soon followed by Everett. The gravediggers’ song, mournful and filled with emotion, begins to swell powerfully, the rhythm seemingly echoing from the earth itself, supported by a resonant and tangible bass.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Pappy stands in a state of thoughtful contemplation, observing the throngs of people gathered around with keen interest. With a sense of protective assurance, he confidently drapes one of his protective arms around Everett, while he allows his other arm to settle securely and supportively around Delmar. Everett finds himself faltering momentarily, engulfed in hesitation, unsure and slightly confused as he tries to comprehend the unfolding events surrounding him. Meanwhile, the band at the event radiates uncontainable joy, their faces lighting up brightly with genuine smiles. Delmar leans closer to Everett, visibly filled with a mounting sense of worry and concern for the situation. Delmar then offers Everett a meaningful and significant look, filled with layers of unspoken communication, which Everett takes a brief moment to ponder and reflect upon. Pappy returns a thoughtful gaze, taking time to carefully consider the scenario laid out before him. On the steps of the meeting hall, people begin streaming out, one after another, making their way from the concert into the warm and inviting embrace of the summer night.

Everett, who is now clean-shaven and no longer burdened with the once-familiar weight of his beard, walks down the steps side by side with Penny. He raises her left hand in tandem with his own in a gesture meant to proudly display their wedding bands to the world, but much to his dismay and displeasure, her finger remains bare, void of any ring, and she quietly walks away. His attention, along with that of everyone else present, is swiftly diverted to a captivating street procession nearby. A fervent crowd, energetically holding torches aloft, jogs behind a man encumbered by the heavy clanking of leg irons and wrist manacles, escorted authoritatively by four policemen in formation, each armed with nightsticks and prepared for any potential disturbance.

Everett, joined by the rest of the Soggy Bottom Boys, makes his way down the steps to meet the approaching criminal, and Delmar cries out in a moment of recognition. It is none other than George Nelson, grinning broadly despite the heavy restraints that bind him, and as he passes by, he turns his head to call back over his shoulder, his spirit undampened by the situation. Delmar, now smiling softly, shakes his head as he watches George gradually disappear into the distance. In the surrounding darkness, the sound of snuffling grows increasingly louder and noticeably nearer. Hidden inside a cupboard, a snout slowly and carefully pushes the door open. As the door swings fully wide, light spills out and reveals several neatly stacked tins of Dapper Dan pomade sitting beside a messy heap of tangled hairnets.

Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy make their way through the dense and tangled woods and emerge unexpectedly into an open clearing where a cabin stands prominently before them. Two menacing goons, armed with shotguns, fall in line behind them and begin pushing them ahead. They reveal, positioned next to a sturdy oak tree, three freshly dug graves, each accompanied by a rough pine coffin positioned at the far edge. The sheriff, Cooley, wearing mirrored sunglasses that reflect back the surroundings, steps confidently off the porch with a drooling hound faithfully at his heels. The goons continue to shove them forcibly toward the tree. Three shirtless black gravediggers, with bandannas tied around their necks, emerge from the depths of the graves, casting glances toward Cooley for direction, just as the drooling hound does. The goons recover their sinister grins and resume their menacing task, while the gravediggers stand beside the graves, leaning wearily on their shovels, with sweat trickling down their faces like glistening tears in the sun. Cooley offers a faint, almost imperceptible smile, and Delmar bows his head solemnly in a silent prayer, a gesture that is soon followed by Everett. The gravediggers’ song, mournful and filled with profound emotion, begins to swell with power, the rhythm seemingly echoing from the earth itself, supported by a resonant and tangible bass.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Pappy stands still, observing the assembled crowd with a thoughtful expression, before making the decision to bring his left arm around Everett's shoulder and his right arm around Delmar's, drawing them closer. Everett, unsure of Pappy’s intentions, pauses with a slight hesitation, his uncertainty etched on his face. Meanwhile, the band members, exuding a sense of joy, beam at the scene, while Delmar, feeling uneasy, leans towards Everett, his brow furrowed with concern. In an attempt to communicate his feelings, Delmar locks eyes with Everett and gives him a look filled with meaning and urgency, prompting Everett to take a moment to contemplate the silent message. Pappy observes the exchange and delivers his own thoughtful appraisal, assessing the situation. As the scene shifts to the steps of the meeting hall, people begin to pour out from the concert, their chatter mingling with the backdrop of the warm summer night. Everett, now clean-shaven, walks down the steps alongside Penny, a sense of anticipation in his stride. He gently raises her left hand with his own, intending to proudly display their wedding bands. Yet, as he gazes at her finger, he realizes it's bare, causing Penny to turn and walk away, leaving Everett momentarily distracted. His attention, along with that of the surrounding crowd, is quickly diverted to a street procession. A group of people, holding torches aloft, jog energetically behind a man shackled in clanking leg irons and wrist manacles, watched over by a quartet of policemen poised with nightsticks, ready for any disturbance. As the Soggy Bottom Boys, including Everett, descend the steps to approach the incoming figure, Delmar lets out a sudden cry, his voice filled with recognition. It is George Nelson, who, despite the weight of his heavy restraints, flashes a grin as he strides forward, turning as he passes to send a call back over his shoulder, his voice spirited. Delmar, a smile spreading across his face, shakes his head as he watches George go, a mixture of amusement and incredulity in his expression. In the enveloping darkness, a sound begins to grow—snuffling, initially faint but growing louder and more pronounced. Within a cupboard, a snout pushes against the door, slowly nosing it open. As the door swings wide, the light catches and reveals several neatly stacked tins of Dapper Dan pomade, sitting next to a cluster of tangled hairnets, a curious arrangement that hints at the chaos of the occupants. Meanwhile, Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy navigate through the woods and emerge into a clearing where a cabin stands alone. Two goons, armed with shotguns, suddenly appear behind them, prodding them forward with an air of authority. As they approach the cabin, their gaze falls upon three freshly dug graves, each lined with rough pine coffins positioned at the far edge. The sheriff, Cooley, adorned with mirrored sunglasses, steps down from the porch, a drooling hound obediently trailing at his heels. The goons renew their efforts, shoving the group toward the oak tree, while three shirtless black gravediggers donning bandannas around their necks rise from the graves and look toward Cooley, awaiting his instructions, mirrored by the expectant hound. As the goons' expressions shift to leering grins, they continue their task with renewed vigor, while the gravediggers, taking up their positions next to the graves, lean on their shovels, the sweat on their faces glistening like tears under the sun’s harsh glare. Cooley, his demeanor enigmatic, allows a faint smile to cross his lips. In response, Delmar lowers his head, engaging in a silent prayer, an act soon mirrored by Everett. The air fills with the mournful swell of the gravediggers' singing, a song that seems to rise from the very earth, underpinned by a deep, resonant bass that echoes across the clearing.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Pappy considers the crowd and embraces Everett and Delmar, prompting Everett's confusion and Delmar's concerned glance, which Everett contemplates briefly. Pappy returns a thoughtful look. As people exit the concert into the warm summer night, Everett, newly clean-shaven, walks with Penny, lifting her hand to show their wedding bands, but her finger is bare, and she walks away. His and the crowd's attention shifts to a street procession where a group with torches jogs behind a man in chains, escorted by policemen with nightsticks. Everett and the Soggy Bottom Boys descend the steps to meet the criminal, revealed to be a grinning George Nelson, who calls back over his shoulder as he passes. Delmar shakes his head, smiling at George's passing. In the darkness, a snout nudges open a cupboard door, revealing tins of Dapper Dan pomade and tangled hairnets. Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy walk through the woods to a clearing with a cabin. Two armed goons force them forward, unveiling freshly dug graves and pine coffins. Sheriff Cooley, with a hound, steps off the porch, and the goons push them toward the tree. Three shirtless gravediggers with bandannas emerge, looking to Cooley and the hound for direction. The goons continue their task as the gravediggers stand, leaning on shovels, their faces glistening with sweat. Cooley smiles faintly, and Delmar bows his head in silent prayer, joined by Everett. The gravediggers' singing fills the air, swelling mournfully with a palpable bass.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Pappy, the town's charismatic but often unpredictable mayor, is considering the crowd, and he drops one arm around Everett and the other around Delmar. Everett hesitates, uncertain of what is happening, while the band, known locally as The Soggy Bottom Boys and famous for their bluegrass music, beams and Delmar leans into Everett with worry. Delmar gives Everett a meaningful look, which Everett considers for a moment. Pappy returns a considered appraisal. On the steps of the historic meeting hall, built in the early 1900s, people stream out of the lively concert into the warm summer night filled with the scent of blooming jasmine. Everett, now relieved of his beard, reminiscent of Ulysses S. Grant's distinctive facial hair, is walking down the steps with Penny and raises her left hand with his own to display their wedding bands, but her finger is bare, signaling unresolved tensions, and she walks off. His attention, along with everyone else's, is drawn to a street procession where a crowd carrying torches jogs behind a man in clanking leg irons and wrist manacles escorted by four policemen with nightsticks in a riot-ready formation from the local state penitentiary. Everett and the Soggy Bottom Boys descend the steps to meet the oncoming criminal, and Delmar cries out. It is George Nelson, the infamous bank robber known as "Baby Face" Nelson, grinning despite his heavy restraints, and as he passes, he turns to call back over his shoulder. Delmar, smiling, shakes his head as he watches him go, reminded of Nelson's previous daring escapes. In the blackness, we hear snuffling getting louder and closer. Inside a cupboard, a snout noses the door open. As the door swings wide, light reveals several neatly stacked tins of Dapper Dan pomade, a popular hair product among men in the 1930s, next to a bunch of tangled hairnets. Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy walk through the woods and emerge into a clearing where a cabin, rumored to be haunted by Civil War spirits, stands before them. Two shotgun-wielding goons fall in behind them and push them forward, revealing next to an ancient oak tree three freshly dug graves with rough pine coffins at the far lip of each grave. The sheriff with mirrored sunglasses, Cooley, known for his ruthless law enforcement tactics, steps off the porch with a drooling hound at his heels, a breed favored for tracking fugitives. The goons shove them toward the tree, and three shirtless black gravediggers with bandannas round their necks emerge from the graves and look to Cooley for guidance, as does the drooling hound. The goons recover their leering grins and resume their task while the gravediggers stand next to the graves, leaning on their shovels, with sweat glistening on their faces like tears. Cooley gives a faint smile, and Delmar bows his head to silently pray, followed by Everett. The singing of the gravediggers begins a mournful swell, and the song, reminiscent of traditional African American spirituals sung by laborers, seemingly rising from the earth itself, is supported by a palpable bass that resonates in the hearts of those present.

High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. The goons shove them toward the tree and three shirtless black gravediggers with bandannas round their necks emerge from the graves and look to Cooley for guidance as does the drooling hound. The goons recover their leering grins and resume their task while the gravediggers stand next to the graves leaning on their shovels with sweat glistening on their faces like tears. Cooley gives a faint smile and Delmar bows his head to silently pray followed by Everett. The singing of the gravediggers begins a mournful swell and the song seemingly rising from the earth itself is supported by a palpable bass.

Everett hesitates uncertain of what is happening while the band beams and Delmar leans into Everett with worry. Delmar gives Everett a meaningful look which Everett considers for a moment. Pappy returns a considered appraisal. On the steps of the meeting hall people stream out of the concert into the warm summer night. Everett now relieved of his beard is walking down the steps with Penny and raises her left hand with his own to display their wedding bands but her finger is bare and she walks off. His attention along with everyone else's is drawn to a street procession where a crowd carrying torches jogs behind a man in clanking leg irons and wrist manacles escorted by four policemen with nightsticks in riotready formation. Everett and the Soggy Bottom Boys descend the steps to meet the oncoming criminal and Delmar cries out. It is George Nelson grinning despite his heavy restraints and as he passes he turns to call back over his shoulder. Delmar smiling shakes his head as he watches him go. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. In the blackness we hear snuffling getting louder and closer. Inside a cupboard a snout noses the door open. As the door swings wide light reveals several neatly stacked tins of Dapper Dan pomade next to a bunch of tangled hairnets. Everett Pete Delmar and Tommy walk through the woods and emerge into a clearing where a cabin stands before them. Two shotgunwielding goons fall in behind them and push them forward revealing next to an oak tree. three freshly dug graves with rough pine coffins at the far lip of each grave. The sheriff with mirrored sunglasses Cooley steps off the porch with a drooling hound at his heels. The goons shove them toward the tree and three shirtless black gravediggers with bandannas round their necks emerge from the graves and look to Cooley for guidance as does the drooling hound. The goons recover their leering grins and resume their task while the gravediggers stand next to the graves leaning on their shovels with sweat glistening on their faces like tears. Cooley gives a faint smile and Delmar bows his head to silently pray followed by Everett. The singing of the gravediggers begins a mournful swell and the song seemingly rising from the earth itself is supported by a palpable bass.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: A parrot is considering the crowd, and it drops one arm around a squirrel and the other around a rabbit. The squirrel hesitates, uncertain of what is happening, while the band beams and the rabbit leans into the squirrel with worry. The rabbit gives the squirrel a meaningful look, which the squirrel considers for a moment. The parrot returns a considered appraisal. On the steps of the meeting hall, penguins stream out of the concert into the warm summer night. The squirrel, now relieved of its beard, is walking down the steps with an owl and raises her left wing with its own to display their wedding bands, but her feather is bare, and she flies off. Its attention, along with everyone else's, is drawn to a street procession where a flock carrying torches jogs behind a dolphin in clanking leg irons and wrist manacles escorted by four foxes with nightsticks in riot-ready formation. The squirrel and the Soggy Bottom Cats descend the steps to meet the oncoming criminal, and the rabbit cries out. It is George Nelson, grinning despite his heavy restraints, and as he passes, he turns to call back over his shoulder. The rabbit, smiling, shakes its head as it watches him go. In the blackness, we hear snuffling getting louder and closer. Inside a cupboard, a trunk noses the door open. As the door swings wide, light reveals several neatly stacked tins of Dapper Dan pomade next to a bunch of tangled hairnets. The squirrel, the penguin, the rabbit, and the tiger walk through the woods and emerge into a clearing where a cabin stands before them. Two shotgun-wielding giraffes fall in behind them and push them forward, revealing next to an oak tree three freshly dug graves with rough pine coffins at the far lip of each grave. The giraffe with mirrored sunglasses, Cooley, steps off the porch with a drooling crocodile at its heels. The giraffes shove them toward the tree, and three shirtless black elephants with bandannas round their necks emerge from the graves and look to Cooley for guidance, as does the drooling crocodile. The giraffes recover their leering grins and resume their task while the elephants stand next to the graves, leaning on their shovels, with sweat glistening on their faces like tears. Cooley gives a faint smile, and the rabbit bows its head to silently pray, followed by the squirrel. The singing of the elephants begins a mournful swell, and the song, seemingly rising from the earth itself, is supported by a palpable bass.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Pappy is considering the gathering, and he drops one arm around Everett and the other around Delmar. Everett hesitates, uncertain of what is happening, while the orchestra beams and Delmar leans into Everett with worry. Delmar gives Everett a meaningful look, which Everett considers for a moment. Pappy returns a considered appraisal. On the steps of the library, people stream out of the exhibition into the warm summer night. Everett, now relieved of his hat, is walking down the steps with Penny and raises her left hand with his own to display their bracelets, but her wrist is bare, and she walks off. His attention, along with everyone else's, is drawn to a street parade where a crowd carrying lanterns jogs behind a man in clattering chains and handcuffs escorted by four guards with batons in riot-ready formation. Everett and the Soggy Bottom Boys descend the steps to meet the oncoming outlaw, and Delmar cries out. It is George Nelson, grinning despite his heavy restraints, and as he passes, he turns to call back over his shoulder. Delmar, smiling, shakes his head as he watches him go. In the blackness, we hear munching getting louder and closer. Inside a cupboard, a paw pushes the door open. As the door swings wide, light reveals several neatly stacked bars of soap next to a bunch of tangled ribbons. Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy walk through the meadow and emerge into a clearing where a barn stands before them. Two crossbow-wielding sentinels fall in behind them and push them forward, revealing next to a birch tree three freshly dug pits with rough stone slabs at the far lip of each pit. The sheriff with mirrored spectacles, Cooley, steps off the porch with a barking terrier at his heels. The sentinels shove them toward the tree, and three shirtless black diggers with scarves round their necks emerge from the pits and look to Cooley for guidance, as does the barking terrier. The sentinels recover their leering grins and resume their task while the diggers stand next to the pits, leaning on their spades, with sweat glistening on their faces like rain. Cooley gives a faint smile, and Delmar bows his head to silently pray, followed by Everett. The singing of the diggers begins a mournful swell, and the song, seemingly rising from the earth itself, is supported by a palpable drumbeat.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Pappy is observing the crowd, and he tosses one arm around Everett and the other around Delmar. Everett giggles, puzzled by what is unfolding, while the band giggles and Delmar leans into Everett with excitement. Delmar throws Everett a curious look, which Everett ponders for a moment. Pappy delivers a quick assessment. On the steps of the meeting hall, people drift out of the concert into the cool summer night. Everett, now relieved of his beard, is leaping down the steps with Penny and raises her left hand with his own to reveal their wedding bands, but her finger is bare, and she strolls away. His focus, along with everyone else's, is drawn to a street celebration where a crowd waving torches ambles behind a man in clanking leg irons and wrist manacles followed by four policemen with nightsticks in parade-ready formation. Everett and the Soggy Bottom Boys skip down the steps to greet the oncoming individual, and Delmar exclaims. It is George Nelson, laughing despite his heavy restraints, and as he walks by, he turns to shout back over his shoulder. Delmar, grinning, nods his head as he watches him go. In the darkness, we hear humming growing louder and closer. Inside a cupboard, a snout bumps the door open. As the door swings wide, light unveils several neatly stacked tins of Dapper Dan pomade next to a cluster of tangled hairnets. Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy wander through the woods and step into a clearing where a cabin rests before them. Two shotgun-wielding goons trail behind them and pull them forward, exposing next to an oak tree three freshly dug graves with rough pine coffins at the far edge of each grave. The sheriff with mirrored sunglasses, Cooley, hops off the porch with a barking hound at his heels. The goons drag them toward the tree, and three shirtless black gravediggers with bandannas round their necks emerge from the graves and look to Cooley for guidance, as does the barking hound. The goons recover their mocking grins and continue their duty while the gravediggers stand next to the graves, resting on their shovels, with sweat glittering on their faces like dew. Cooley offers a gentle smirk, and Delmar bows his head to silently muse, followed by Everett. The humming of the gravediggers starts a joyful swell, and the tune, seemingly floating from the earth itself, is accompanied by a vibrant bass.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The mailbox is considering the bookshelf, and it drops one arm around the doorknob and the other around the lampshade. The doorknob hesitates, uncertain of what is happening, while the pencil beams and the lampshade leans into the doorknob with worry. The lampshade gives the doorknob a meaningful look, which the doorknob considers for a moment. The mailbox returns a considered appraisal. On the steps of the basketball court, clouds stream out of the playground into the warm summer night. The doorknob, now relieved of its scarf, is walking down the steps with the umbrella and raises the umbrella's left hand with its own to display their engagement rings, but the umbrella's finger is bare, and it walks off. Its attention, along with everyone else's, is drawn to a bookshelf procession where a bookshelf carrying lanterns jogs behind a calculator in clattering bells and wrist bracelets escorted by four marshmallows with toothpicks in riot-ready formation. The doorknob and the Rocky Bottom Bananas descend the steps to meet the oncoming violin, and the lampshade cries out. It is Albert Einstein, grinning despite its heavy restraints, and as it passes, it turns to call back over its shoulder. The lampshade, smiling, shakes its head as it watches it go. In the blackness, we hear honking getting louder and closer. Inside a pantry, a paw noses the door open. As the door swings wide, light reveals several neatly stacked jars of Peanut Butter pomade next to a bunch of tangled curtain rods. The doorknob, the stapler, the lampshade, and the toaster walk through the woods and emerge into a clearing where a sailboat stands before them. Two tambourine-wielding flamingos fall in behind them and push them forward, revealing next to an apple tree three freshly dug tunnels with rough pine barrels at the far lip of each tunnel. The saxophone with mirrored shoelaces, Jukebox, steps off the porch with a drooling frog at its heels. The flamingos shove them toward the tree, and three shirtless blue astronomers with chandeliers round their necks emerge from the tunnels and look to Jukebox for guidance, as does the drooling frog. The flamingos recover their leering grins and resume their task while the astronomers stand next to the tunnels, leaning on their rakes, with sweat glistening on their cheeks like raindrops. Jukebox gives a faint smile, and the lampshade bows its head to silently pray, followed by the doorknob. The singing of the astronomers begins a mournful swell, and the song, seemingly rising from the sky itself, is supported by a palpable treble.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Bobby is studying the curtain, and he lifts one leg around Marvin and the other around Lester. Marvin pauses, unsure of what is unfolding, while the choir glows and Lester slumps into Marvin with concern. Lester shoots Marvin a puzzled glance, which Marvin ponders for a while. Bobby returns an attentive scrutiny. On the balcony of the movie house, characters pour out of the theater into the cool autumn evening. Marvin, now rid of his hat, is skipping down the balcony with Ruby and waves her right hand with his own to showcase their friendship bracelets, but her wrist is empty, and she skips away. His focus, along with everyone else's, is attracted to a sidewalk parade where a group carrying lanterns skips behind a dog in jangling chains and leg cuffs flanked by four guards with flashlights in party-ready formation. Marvin and the Soggy Bottom Pals skip down the balcony to greet the approaching trickster, and Lester laughs out. It is Charlie Nelson, chuckling despite his heavy burdens, and as he passes, he twists to shout back over his elbow. Lester, grinning, wags his head as he watches him disappear. In the darkness, we hear rustling getting softer and farther. Inside a pantry, a whisker pushes the door shut. As the door swings closed, light fades from several loosely stacked tins of Dapper Dan pomade next to a heap of tangled wires. Marvin, Carl, Lester, and Billy walk through the meadow and step into a clearing where a hut stretches before them. Two knife-wielding thugs slip in behind them and pull them backward, exposing next to a pine tree three freshly filled pits with rough stone markers at the near edge of each pit. The deputy with glossy goggles, Charlie, strolls onto the lawn with a barking cat at his side. The thugs drag them toward the tree, and three coatless pale gardeners with ribbons around their wrists rise from the pits and turn to Charlie for direction, as does the barking cat. The thugs recover their sneering cackles and continue their task while the gardeners stand next to the pits, leaning on their rakes, with sweat shimmering on their necks like jewels. Charlie gives a subtle nod, and Lester lifts his chin to quietly cheer, followed by Marvin. The chanting of the gardeners begins a sorrowful rise, and the tune, seemingly drifting from the sky itself, is supported by a tangible treble.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Pappy is observing the forest, and he places one hand on Everett's shoulder and the other on Delmar's. Everett pauses, puzzled about what is occurring, while the choir glows and Delmar nudges Everett with concern. Delmar gives Everett a significant glance, which Everett ponders briefly. Pappy returns a thoughtful estimation. On the stairs of the library, people march out of the exhibition into the cool autumn evening. Everett, now without his hat, is strolling down the stairs with Penny and lifts her right hand with his own to exhibit their friendship bracelets, but her wrist is empty, and she strolls away. His focus, along with everyone else's, is drawn to a park rally where a mass carrying lanterns dances behind a man in jangling chains and ankle cuffs accompanied by four firefighters with axes in parade-ready formation. Everett and the Soggy Bottom Boys ascend the stairs to greet the approaching prankster, and Delmar calls out. It is George Nelson, smiling despite his heavy shackles, and as he goes by, he turns to shout back over his head. Delmar, chuckling, shakes his head as he watches him depart. In the darkness, we hear rustling getting louder and nearer. Inside a drawer, a paw pushes the lid open. As the lid swings wide, illumination reveals several neatly stacked bricks of Dapper Dan pomade next to a pile of twisted fishing nets. Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy wander through the meadow and step into a glade where a tent stands before them. Two bat-wielding bullies fall in behind them and prod them onward, revealing next to a maple tree three freshly filled pits with rough wooden boxes at the far edge of each pit. The ranger with mirrored goggles, Cooley, steps off the veranda with a slobbering beast at his heels. The bullies nudge them toward the tree, and three shirtless black gardeners with scarves around their necks emerge from the pits and look to Cooley for direction, as does the slobbering beast. The bullies regain their mocking grins and continue their mission while the gardeners stand next to the pits, leaning on their rakes, with perspiration gleaming on their faces like raindrops. Cooley offers a subtle grin, and Delmar tilts his head to silently meditate, followed by Everett. The humming of the gardeners begins a sorrowful rise, and the tune, seemingly emanating from the soil itself, is supported by an audible echo.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Gramps is inspecting the parade, and he tosses one leg over Marvin and the other over Clyde. Marvin falters, unsure of what is unfolding, while the choir grins and Clyde leans into Marvin with doubt. Clyde offers Marvin a significant glance, which Marvin ponders briefly. Gramps returns a thoughtful assessment. On the stairs of the assembly hall, individuals flood out of the theater into the cool autumn dawn. Marvin, now free of his hat, is climbing up the stairs with Lucy and raises her right foot with his own to display their engagement rings, but her toe is bare, and she strolls away. His gaze, along with everyone else's, shifts to a forest parade where a group carrying lanterns trots behind a woman in jangling chains and ankle bracelets escorted by four firefighters with axes in emergency-ready stance. Marvin and the Gloomy Top Men climb the stairs to greet the arriving fugitive, and Clyde shouts out. It is Charlie Robbins, smiling despite his weighty bonds, and as he passes, he swivels to shout back over his elbow. Clyde, laughing, nods his head as he observes him leave. In the darkness, we hear rustling getting louder and nearer. Inside a drawer, a paw pushes the cover open. As the cover swings wide, illumination reveals several neatly piled jars of Silky Sam gel next to a pile of twisted ribbons. Marvin, Eddie, Clyde, and Johnny stroll through the desert and step into an opening where a shack stands before them. Two rifle-toting ruffians fall in behind them and prod them onward, revealing next to a birch three freshly filled pits with rough metal containers at the far edge of each pit. The marshal with reflective glasses, Bailey, strides off the deck with a barking terrier at his side. The ruffians jolt them toward the plant, and three bare-chested white laborers with scarves around their waists climb out of the pits and glance to Bailey for direction, as does the barking terrier. The ruffians regain their smirking grins and continue their duty while the laborers stand beside the pits, resting on their spades, with dew glimmering on their brows like rain. Bailey shows a slight grin, and Clyde lowers his gaze to softly meditate, followed by Marvin. The humming of the laborers begins a sorrowful rise, and the melody, seemingly emerging from the sky itself, is accompanied by a resonant trumpet.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Pappy observes the crowd, placing an arm around Everett and Delmar. Everett is unsure, while Delmar looks at him worriedly. As people exit the concert hall, Everett, now clean-shaven, shows Penny's bare left hand, hinting at marital issues. A torchlit procession follows George Nelson, manacled and escorted by police; Delmar smiles at Nelson's cheerful demeanor. In the woods, Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy encounter two armed goons who force them towards three fresh graves. Sheriff Cooley, accompanied by his dog, watches them. The goons push the group forward as the gravediggers, led by Cooley, wait for instructions. Delmar prays silently, joined by Everett, as the gravediggers' mournful song swells from the earth.
